title: How to Take Hand Held Pictures Indoors Without Flash

steps.headline: Set your camera to "Aperture Priority" and open the lens aperture up wide.
steps.description: Why "A"? Because indoors hand-held your main enemy is camera shake, and to defeat it you'll need as much light as possible. Depth of field will have to take a back seat.

steps.headline: Compose your picture.
steps.description: Look at the shutter speed. The slowest shutter speed at which camera shake is not a factor is any speed higher than the focal length of your lens (should be marked on the lens) ex. 45mm. If you're at or faster than that, take the pic.

steps.headline: If you're slower than 1/45, increase the ISO if possible.
steps.description: If you're faster, you may be able to reduce the ISO to get a less noisy picture.

steps.headline: You can now shoot using only the ISO dial to set the exposure.
steps.description: In a dark room, boost the ISO. In a lighter room, knock it down a bit. The aperture setting will always be locked at wide-open and the shutter speed will always be the best available for controlling shake.

Look at the shutter speed. The slowest shutter speed at which camera shake is not a factor is any speed higher than the focal length of your lens (should be marked on the lens) ex. 45mm. If you're at or faster than that, take the pic. If you're slower than 1/45, increase the ISO if possible. If you're faster, you may be able to reduce the ISO to get a less noisy picture. You can now shoot using only the ISO dial to set the exposure. In a dark room, boost the ISO. In a lighter room, knock it down a bit. The aperture setting will always be locked at wide-open and the shutter speed will always be the best available for controlling shake.
